writings.title: Creating and Measuring Mutation Profiles Within TFBSs
writings.purpose: Research Report for Duke Center for Genomic & Computational Biology
writings.description: We still do not understand how mutations arise within transcription factor binding sites, implicated as a cause of some cancers. I aimed to replicate previous findings correlating these regions with higher mutation rates, and to optimize the computationally expensive task of creating mutation profiles.

writings.title: The SSRI Fluoxetine Causes Shorter Catch States for Mussels in Preliminary Study
How I Built This Website
writings.description: Designing, building and hosting a website from scratch can seem like a daunting task. I wrote this guide to explain how I created mine, and to help others do the same.

The Nature–Culture Dependency, and Mutual Destruction, in ‘Pom Poko’
Characterizing Dietary Components in Processed Foods Through Next-Generation Sequencing
writings.purpose: Research Report for Duke Molecular Genetics & Microbiology
writings.description: Targeted amplicon sequencing can be used to qualitatively identify species components of a pooled DNA sample. I evaluated whether the food-species components of processed foods can be identified, and if the next-generation sequencing strategy is useful in quantification.

writings.purpose: Investigative Article for Duke Sanford School of Public Policy

writings.title: Did Phil Berger Pay Himself $2,000 Each Month in Rent?
writings.purpose: Fact-Check Article for Duke Sanford School of Public Policy
writings.description: I disputed an opponent’s ad against the N.C. state Senate leader, “the most powerful man in state politics.” But, along the way, I also discovered paper trails to potentially unlawful spending by his campaign—paying himself thousands of dollars each month in “rent” to his own shell company.

writings.title: A Fountainhead of Woe at the Durham Convention Center
writings.purpose: Feature Article for Duke Sanford School of Public Policy
writings.description: Installed almost 30 years ago, the fountain outside the local center’s front doors have caused its administrators headaches for years, plagued by continual breakage and expensive repairs. City politics, expert interviews, oral history—I stopped at nothing to tap into this incredibly pressing issue.
